Initial focus on understanding the particle accelerator M and velocity selector N.
In the particle accelerator M, the particle is accelerated from rest to some velocity.
Energy gained by the particle equals the work done by the electric field in the accelerator.
Focus on the velocity selector part due to lack of specifics about the accelerator.
For a particle to pass through the selector along a straight line, electric and magnetic forces must balance: qE = qvB.
Solving for velocity v: v = E/B.
The first particle with mass m and charge q is accelerated to velocity v by M and passes through N straight.
The second particle with mass 2m and charge q is accelerated by M but deviates by d.
Considering that both particles are accelerated to the same velocity v by M.
According to the velocity selector principle, only particles with velocity v = E/B pass straight through.
If the particle has a different velocity, it will experience a net force and deviate.
The second particle deviates by d, indicating a velocity different from v = E/B.
Both particles are accelerated by M to velocity v, questioning why the second particle deviates.
Considering the possibility of different velocities based on mass.
Assuming the accelerator M is an electrostatic accelerator with a potential difference V.
Energy gained by a particle in an electrostatic accelerator is qV, which equals its kinetic energy.
For the first particle with mass m and charge q: Ek1 = qV = (1/2)mv^2, so v = sqrt(2qV/m).
For the second particle with mass 2m and charge q: Ek2 = qV = (1/2)(2m)v'^2, so v' = sqrt(qV/m).
